questions.text: A primigravida with 32 weeks of gestation presents to ER with complaint of watery discharge per vaginum since past 4 hours. No abdominal pain. She is perceiving fetal movements well. On examination, uterus is relaxed, FHS 154 bpm, regular. Cervix seems closed on P/S but a pool of liquor is seen in posterior fornix. Antibiotic of choice in this case would be:
questions.solution:
It is a case of PPROM(i.e ,rupture of membranes before 37 weeks of gestation.).In PROM rupture of membranes occurs >37 weeks but before onset of labor.

  • The antibiotic of choice would be erythromycin 250 mg four times a day for 10 days or until the woman is in established labour (whichever is sooner).
  • Penicillin may be used in women who cannot tolerate erythromycin.
  • Co-amoxiclav should be avoided as it is associated with an increased risk of neonatal necrotising enterocolitis.

Options:

  • b) Co-amoxiclav
    While it covers a broad range of organisms, it is not the first-line choice in cases of preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM).
  • c) Metronidazole
    This antibiotic is used for anaerobic infections but is not the first choice in cases of PPROM unless there's evidence of a specific anaerobic infection.
  • d) Imipenem
    This is a broad-spectrum carbapenem antibiotic typically reserved for severe infections and would not be the first-line choice in this scenario.

KEY TAKEAWAY- This antibiotic is effective against group B Streptococcus (GBS) and other pathogens that can cause chorioamnionitis, especially in preterm rupture of membranes.

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 73, Care of women presenting with suspected preterm prelabor rupture of membranes

questions.text: Cut-off of fetal fibronectin test to rule out preterm labour:
questions.solution:
• Fetal Fibronectin (fFN) is present in high concentrations in maternal blood and amniotic fluid, fFN is thought to function in intercellular adhesion during implantation and in maintenance of placental adherence to uterine decidua.
  • Detected in cervicovaginal secretions in women who have normal pregnancies with intact membranes at term, fFN appears to reflect stromal remodelling of the cervix before labor.
  • Qualitative and quantitative fFN levels are measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays, and values exceeding 50 ng/mL are considered positive.

KEY TAKEAWAY- fetal fibronectin testing is negative if concentration 50 ng/ml or less, it is unlikely that she would end up in preterm labour in the next 7 days.

Reference: NICE guidelines on preterm labour & birth

choices.text: Beta lactam antibiotics with clavulanic acid increase the risk of NEC in the fetus
Antibiotics need to be given prior to rupture of membranes
Antibiotics decrease the risk of maternal & fetal infections significantly

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the ORACLE trial?
questions.solution:
This statement is false. The ORACLE trial showed that the administration of antibiotics after rupture of membranes can still be beneficial, challenging the notion that they must be given beforehand.

Options: a) Macrolide antibiotics are recommended
The ORACLE trial investigated the efficacy of antibiotics, including macrolides, in the context of preterm labor and rupture of membranes, and it was found that certain macrolides could be beneficial.

b) Beta lactam antibiotics with clavulanic acid increase the risk of NEC in the fetus
The findings from the ORACLE trial indicated that the use of beta-lactam antibiotics with clavulanic acid is associated with an increased risk of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) in preterm infants.

c) d) Antibiotics decrease the risk of maternal & fetal infections significantly
The trial demonstrated that antibiotic treatment does reduce the risk of maternal and fetal infections, validating this statement.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • Antibiotics are to be given only in the setting of Rupture of Membranes, not prior to that, in order to prevent maternal & fetal infections.
  • Macrolide antibiotics like erythromycin are advocated.
  • Co-amoxiclav should be avoided as it increases the risk of NEC in the fetus.

choices.text: 14-24 weeks is the ideal time frame
TVS is better as compared to TAS
USG indicated cerclage is recommended in the event of funneling of cervix with or without cervical shortening

questions.text: All of the following are correct regarding the use of sonography to diagnose cervical incompetence, except:
questions.solution:
An ultrasound-indicated cerclage is not recommended for funnelling of the cervix (dilatation of the internal os on ultrasound) in the absence of cervical shortening to 25 mm or less (the closed length of the cervix).

Other options:

  1. a) 14-24 weeks is the ideal time frame
    This is correct; the ideal time frame for assessing cervical incompetence via sonography is typically between 14 and 24 weeks of gestation.
  2. b) TVS is better as compared to TAS
    Transvaginal sonography (TVS) is indeed considered superior to transabdominal sonography (TAS) for evaluating the cervix due to its higher resolution and closer proximity to the cervix.
  3. c) Maternal bladder should be empty
    This statement is accurate. An empty bladder is preferred for transvaginal sonography to obtain a clearer view of the cervix.

Key TAKEAWAY-

CERVICAL CERCLAGE IS NOT RECOMMENDED:

questions.text: All of the following comprise the high risk group for cervical incompetence, where USG surveillance of Cervical length is advocated, except:
questions.solution:
previous preterm prelabour rupture of membranes (PPROM) less than 34 weeks & NOT 37 weeks.

Women at high risk of preterm labour where USG surveillance is required include:

  • those with a previous preterm birth or second trimester loss (16-34 weeks’ gestation) (OPTION D)
  • previous preterm prelabour rupture of membranes (PPROM) less than 34 weeks & NOT 37 weeks
  • previous use of cerclage
  • known uterine variant
  • intrauterine adhesions (OPTION B)
  • history of trachelectomy (OPTION C)

These women are recommended to be reviewed by a preterm prevention specialist by 12 weeks where possible, or with the dating scan whichever is sooner, and offered transvaginal cervix scanning as a secondary screening test every 2-4 weeks between 16 and 24 weeks

KEY TAKEAWAY- Previous preterm prelabour rupture of membranes (PPROM) less than 34 weeks is a high risk group for cervical incompetence.

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 73 Preterm Labour & Birth, PPROM

choices.text: Use of dexamethasone resulted in lower incidence of IVH as compared to betamethasone
Betamethasone resulted in lesser risk of maternal chorioamnionitis in comparison with dexamethasone
Betamethasone finds its place in WHO's Essential Medicines List
Betamethasone double salt has sodium phosphate which is soluble & acetate, which is insoluble

questions.text: False about betamethasone/dexamethasone:
questions.solution:
• Dexamethasone (& not betamethasone) is in the WHO Essential Medicines list. It is cheap, inexpensive & hence widely used for inducing fetal lung maturity.
  • Betamethasone is available in two formulations. Betamethasone sodium phosphate is soluble with a short half-life, while betamethasone sodium acetate is insoluble and has a long half-life. In many countries the two preparations are available in a 50:50 mixture.

Options:

a) Use of dexamethasone resulted in lower incidence of IVH as compared to betamethasone
This statement is true. Dexamethasone has been associated with a lower incidence of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) compared to betamethasone in some studies.

b) Betamethasone resulted in lesser risk of maternal chorioamnionitis in comparison with dexamethasone
This statement is true. Betamethasone has been linked to a lower risk of chorioamnionitis compared to dexamethasone.

d) Betamethasone double salt has sodium phosphate which is soluble & acetate, which is insoluble
This statement is true. The double salt formulation of betamethasone contains both a soluble component (sodium phosphate) and an insoluble component (acetate).

KEY TAKEAWAY-

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 74, Antenatal corticosteroids to reduce neonatal morbidity & mortality

choices.text: A ratio >2 has a low risk for RDS
Not reliable in the presence of blood or meconium
Lecithin is predominantly produced by Type I pneumocytes

questions.text: One of the tests to assess fetal pulmonary maturity is the Lecithin : Sphingomyelin ratio. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the L:S ratio:--
questions.solution:
• Phosphatidylcholine, also referred to as lecithin, is one of the phospholipids present in mature surfactant. It is stored and secreted by organelles called lamellar bodies.
  • These organelles appear after 22 to 24 weeks gestation. Before the 28th week of gestation, the fetal lung primarily synthesizes sphingomyelin, a nonpulmonary lipid.
  • At approximately 32 weeks gestation, the number of lamellar bodies increases, which translates into increased surfactant present in the fetal lungs and amniotic fluid. At this point in lung maturity, the ratio of lecithin and sphingomyelin are relatively equal in concentration.
  • By 35 weeks of gestation, the mature surfactant has been produced and is marked by a sharp increase in the concentration of lecithin in the fetal lungs and amniotic fluid.
  • The lecithin to sphingomyelin ratio of 2:1 or greater is characteristic of mature fetal lungs.
  • Fetuses delivered prior to this gestational age are at increased risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

Options:

a) It is <0.5 at 20 weeks
This statement is correct. The L:S ratio is typically less than 0.5 at 20 weeks of gestation, indicating immature fetal lungs.

b) A ratio >2 has a low risk for RDS
This statement is correct. An L:S ratio greater than 2 is associated with a lower risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

c) Not reliable in the presence of blood or meconium
This statement is correct. The presence of blood or meconium can interfere with the accuracy of the L:S ratio, making it less reliable

Key TAKEAWAY- Lecithin produced by Type II pneumocytes.

Reference: NICE guidelines on Preterm Labour & Preterm Birth

questions.text: A 21 year old primigravida, known case of mitral stenosis, presents to ER at 33 weeks' gestation with lower abdominal pain, increasing in intensity, duration & frequency for the past 6 hours. On examination, uterine contractions are present & adequate ~ 3 in 10 minutes. Cervix is 3 cm dilated, effacement 50-60%, vertex at -3 station. CTG is reassuring. The tocolytic of choice would be:
questions.solution:
Atosiban is an oxytocin receptor antagonist specifically indicated for the management of preterm labor and is preferable in patients with heart conditions such as mitral stenosis due to its minimal cardiovascular side effects.

Options:

a) Nifedipine
Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that is often used as a tocolytic agent; however, it may have cardiovascular effects that can be concerning in patients with pre-existing heart conditions.

b) Ritodrine
Ritodrine is a beta-agonist that can be used for tocolysis, but it may also increase heart rate and have cardiovascular side effects, which can be problematic in patients with mitral stenosis.

c) Isoxsuprine
Isoxsuprine is another beta-agonist used for tocolysis but carries similar concerns regarding cardiovascular effects in patients with heart conditions.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • Atosiban is an oxytocin receptor antagonist. It is the safest tocolytic to be used in a woman with heart disease.
  • Beta 2 mimetics like ritodrine & Isoxsuprine may increase the risk of pulmonary edema.
  • Nifedipine, on the other hand may decompensate the existing pathology because of reflex tachycardia.

In the above case, there is a history of heart disease. So, instead of nifedipine Atosiban is preferred in this case.

questions.text: Most important risk factor for preterm labour is:
questions.solution:
• The most important risk factor for preterm labor is a prior preterm birth.
  • The recurrent preterm delivery risk for women with a preterm first delivery was threefold greater than that of women whose first neonate was born at term

Options:

a) Uterine anomalies
Uterine anomalies can increase the risk of preterm labor but are not the most significant risk factor compared to others.

c) Smoking
Smoking is a known risk factor for preterm labor and other pregnancy complications but is not as significant as a history of prior preterm birth.

d) Shorter inter-pregnancy interval
A short inter-pregnancy interval can increase the risk of preterm birth but is not the most important risk factor compared to prior preterm birth.

KEY Takeaway -

choices.text: Decreases the incidence of intraventricular hemorrhage
Decreases the incidence of neonatal hypoglycemia
Decreases the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis

questions.text: A 26 year old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation is admitted to Obstetric Ward with diagnosis of preterm labour. She is put on antenatal corticosteroid therapy. All of the following are benefits of this therapy to the fetus, except:
questions.solution:
Antenatal corticosteroid therapy increases the incidence of neonatal hypoglycemia, more with betamethasone as compared to dexamethasone.

Options:

a) Increases fetal lung maturity
Antenatal corticosteroids significantly enhance fetal lung maturity by promoting the production of surfactant, which is crucial for reducing respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

b) Decreases the incidence of intraventricular hemorrhage
Corticosteroids are associated with a reduced risk of intraventricular hemorrhage in preterm infants, improving their overall neurological outcomes.

d) Decreases the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis
Antenatal corticosteroids have been shown to reduce the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis in preterm infants, contributing to improved gastrointestinal outcomes.

Key TAKEAWAY-

choices.text: Amniotic fluid absorbance at 450 nm wavelength

questions.text: All of the following are tests to detect fetal lung maturity, except?
questions.solution:
• Amniotic fluid spectrophotometric analysis for bilirubin, used to assess the severity of fetal involvement in isoimmunized pregnancies, is done at 450 nm.
  • Spectrophotometric analysis for fetal lung maturity is done at 650 nm.

Options:

a) Lecithin: Sphingomyelin ratio
The Lecithin: Sphingomyelin ratio is a well-established test for assessing fetal lung maturity. A higher ratio indicates better fetal lung maturity and lower risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

b) Phosphatidylglycerol estimation
Phosphatidylglycerol (PG) is a component of surfactant produced by the fetal lungs. The presence of PG in amniotic fluid is a strong indicator of fetal lung maturity.

c) TDx FLM
The TDx FLM (Fetal Lung Maturity) test is a commercial assay used to measure the levels of surfactant in amniotic fluid, specifically looking for the presence of lecithin and other surfactant components to assess lung maturity.

Key TAKEAWAY -

questions.text: A 26 year young G4P0A3 woman is referred to an infertility specialist at 14 weeks of gestation. She has a history of 3 spontaneous abortions in second trimester, all of which were painless, followed by expulsion of products of conception. Owing to her prior losses, she was planned for an elective cervical cerclage and the following technique was made use of. How do we better know this method of cerclage?
questions.solution:
• Of the two vaginal cerclage operations, most use the simpler procedure developed by McDonald (1963) using PURSE STRING SUTURES is shown in the figure.

Option wise explanation:

Key TAKEAWAY- PURSE STRING SUTURES used in McDonald's cerclage.

choices.text: Insulin like growth factor binding protein

questions.text: A 19-year old G1P0 presents to the Emergency Room at 30 weeks of gestation with complaints of lower abdominal pain since 6 hours & leaking per vaginum since 2 hours. On a per speculum examination, liquor was seen collecting in the posterior fornix. To ensure the nature of this fluid, AMNISURE test was performed. This relies upon detection of which of the following substances to confirm that the fluid is amniotic in nature?
questions.solution:
• The newest confirmatory test is the AmniSure, which is a point of care immunochromatographic assay that detects trace amounts of placental alpha microglobulin-1 protein (PAMG-1) OPTION A in vaginal fluid after rupture of fetal membranes.
  • The analytical sensitivity of the test has been set at 5 ng/mL.
  • Actim Partus is another such recent advancement in diagnosis of PROM which detects IGFBP-1 (Insulin like growth factor binding protein-1) OPTION B
  • Fetal fibronectin is used to predict the risk of preterm labour (OPTION C)
  • Cell free fetal DNA is used for prenatal diagnosis (OPTION D)

Key TAKEAWAY- AmniSure is a point of care immunochromatographic assay that detects trace amounts of placental alpha microglobulin-1 protein (PAMG-1) in vaginal fluid after rupture of fetal membranes.

Reference: ACOG guidelines for rupture of membranes evaluation

questions.text: Which of the following uterine anomalies is associated with the highest risk of preterm labour?
questions.solution:
Unicornuate uterus This anomaly involves a single uterine horn due to the failure of one Mullerian duct to develop.

  • Risk of preterm labor: Highest
  • It has the most significant association with preterm labor, miscarriage, and other pregnancy complications due to limited uterine space.

Optionwise explanation:

a. Arcuate uterus

  • This anomaly involves a mild indentation of the uterine fundus.
  • Risk of preterm labor: Low
  • It is considered a less severe form of a uterine anomaly with minimal impact on pregnancy outcomes.

b. Septate uterus

  • In this condition, a fibrous or muscular septum divides the uterine cavity.
  • Risk of preterm labor: Moderate
  • It increases the risk of miscarriage and preterm labor but not as high as a unicornuate uterus.

d. Bicornuate uterus

  • The uterus is heart-shaped, with two uterine cavities.
  • Risk of preterm labor: Moderate
  • There is an increased risk of preterm labor but not as high as in a unicornuate uterus.

KEY TAKEAWAY-Women with uterine abnormalities and a short cervix on TVS have a 13-fold increase in spontaneous PTB (Pre Term Birth), with those having a unicornuate uterus having the highest rate of PTB.

questions.text: A 24 year old primigravida, 41+6 weeks of gestation presents to the labour ward, has a reassuring fetal trace, cephalic baby with adequate pelvis, and a Bishop score of 4. Which of the following methods for IOL should not be preferred?
questions.solution:
This method is not preferred when the cervix is unfavorable, as amniotomy (artificial rupture of membranes) requires a more favorable cervix to be effective. In this patient, with a Bishop score of 4, the cervix is not yet ripe, so amniotomy with oxytocin is not ideal.

Option-wise explanation:

a. Dinoprostone vaginal gel

  • Explanation: This is a prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) preparation used for cervical ripening and is commonly used in cases of unfavorable cervix. It is appropriate in this scenario.

b. Low-dose oral misoprostol tablets

  • Explanation: Oral misoprostol (PGE1) is used for cervical ripening and labor induction, particularly in cases where the cervix is not favorable. It can be a safe option when used in low doses for cervical ripening.

c. Low-dose vaginal misoprostol tablets

  • Explanation: Vaginal misoprostol tablets are another form of PGE1 that can be used for both cervical ripening and labor induction. Low-dose vaginal misoprostol is often used and is considered effective.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • For women with a Bishop score of 6 or less, offer induction of labour with dinoprostone as vaginal tablet, vaginal gel or controlled-release vaginal delivery system or with low dose (25 microgram) oral misoprostol tablets.
  • For women with a Bishop score of more than 6, offer induction of labour with amniotomy and an intravenous oxytocin infusion.

Reference: NICE guidelines on Induction of Labour

questions.text: All of the following are indications for induction of labour, except:
questions.solution:
This is not an indication for induction of labor. In cases of active genital herpes, the preferred management is usually cesarean delivery to prevent transmission of the virus to the neonate during vaginal delivery. Induction is not routinely recommended unless there are other compelling reasons.

Option-wise explanation:

a. Severe preeclampsia >34 weeks

  • Induction of labor is indicated to prevent maternal and fetal complications. Severe preeclampsia poses risks such as placental abruption, HELLP syndrome, and fetal distress, making it a clear indication for induction.

b. PROM >34 weeks

  • Prelabor rupture of membranes (PROM) beyond 34 weeks is an indication for induction. After this gestational age, the risk of infection increases, and the benefits of delivery usually outweigh the risks of waiting.

c. Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy ~35-37 weeks

  • Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy can lead to complications such as fetal distress and stillbirth. Induction of labor is typically recommended around 37 weeks to minimize risks to the fetus.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

questions.text: If a woman has preterm premature rupture of membranes, do not carry out induction of labour before how many weeks unless there are additional obstetric indications:--
questions.solution:
• If a woman has preterm premature rupture of membranes, do not carry out induction of labour before 34+0 weeks unless there are additional obstetric indications (for example, infection or fetal compromise).
  • After 34 weeks, the risks of complications associated with prematurity are significantly reduced, and the benefits of delivery often outweigh the risks.

Option-wise explanation:

a. 32 weeks

  • Inducing labor before 32 weeks is generally avoided unless there are significant obstetric indications, as the risks of neonatal morbidity and mortality are higher in this gestational age.

b. 33 weeks

  • Similar to 32 weeks, induction at 33 weeks is usually not performed unless there are strong clinical indications, given the associated risks for the preterm infant.

d. 36 weeks

  • By 36 weeks, the risk of complications for the neonate is much lower, and labor can be induced if there are obstetric indications. However, the question specifies "before how many weeks," making this option incorrect in the context of the question.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

NICE guidelines on Induction of Labour

choices.text: Uterine tachysystole may be seen with its use in 1-5% of women
Oxytocin induction that follows prostaglandin use for cervical ripening should be delayed for 6 to 12 hours following PGE2 gel administration
It is available in gel form & as a vaginal insert tablet

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding dinoprostone?
questions.solution:
Dinoprostone is actually a PGE2 analogue, not a PGE1 analogue. Misoprostol, on the other hand, is a PGE1 analogue.

Here's the option-wise explanation:

b. Uterine tachysystole may be seen with its use in 1-5% of women

  • One of the side effects of dinoprostone use is uterine tachysystole, which is defined as more than five contractions in a 10-minute window, observed in around 1-5% of women. This can lead to fetal distress if not managed appropriately.

c. Oxytocin induction that follows prostaglandin use for cervical ripening should be delayed for 6 to 12 hours following PGE2 gel administration

  • After using dinoprostone for cervical ripening, it's recommended to delay oxytocin induction for 6 to 12 hours to avoid overstimulation of the uterus, which could lead to hyperstimulation or fetal compromise.

d. It is available in gel form & as a vaginal insert tablet

  • Dinoprostone is available in both gel form and as a vaginal insert (tablet or pessary), commonly used for cervical ripening before labor induction. Each formulation has its specific indications and benefits, offering flexibility in administration.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • Dinoprostone is a synthetic analogue of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2). It is commercially available in three forms: a gel, a time-release vaginal insert, and a 20-mg suppository.
  • Uterine tachysystole follows vaginally administered PGE2 in 1 to 5 percent of women.
  • Uterine tachysystole is defined as >5 contractions in a 10-minute period.
  • It should always be qualified by the presence or absence of fetal heart rate abnormalities.
  • Oxytocin induction that follows prostaglandin use for cervical ripening should be delayed for 6 to 12 hours following PGE2 gel administration or for at least 30 minutes after removal of the vaginal insert. These guidelines stem from the risk of uterine tachysystole.

questions.text: A 25 year old primigravida reports to labour room at 39 weeks+5 days gestation with pain in lower abdomen for last 6 hours. On examination, strong uterine contractions are present, fundal height corresponds to period of gestation, head is 4/5th palpable, FHR 150 bpm. Cervix is 4 cm dilated, 60% effaced, bag of membranes bulging. Her vitals were stable. The resident posted in LR, did an amniotomy at this stage. The CTG started showing decelerations with dips going upto 80 bpm. The liquor however was clear. Which is the most likely reason for these findings?
questions.solution:
• In the question, fetal head is 4/5th palpable per abdomen, that means it is not yet engaged.
  • Regardless of the indication, amniotomy is associated with a risk of cord prolapse. To minimize this risk, disengagement of the fetal head during amniotomy is avoided. Some clinicians prefer to rupture membranes during a contraction. In many of these cases, however, membranes tear and fluid is lost rapidly. Because of the risk of cord prolapse, or rarely placental abruption, the fetal heart rate is assessed before and immediately after amniotomy.

Option-wise Explanation:

  • a. Abruptio placentae: Abruptio placentae refers to premature separation of the placenta, typically associated with vaginal bleeding and uterine tenderness. The clear liquor in this case makes abruptio placentae less likely, and the sudden fetal heart rate (FHR) decelerations without other signs of placental abruption further reduce the likelihood of this diagnosis.
  • c. Vasa previa: Vasa previa involves fetal blood vessels traversing the membranes near the cervix, which can rupture during labor, leading to fetal bleeding. However, vasa previa would be expected to cause blood-stained amniotic fluid, not clear liquor, and typically results in rapid fetal exsanguination, not just decelerations.
  • d. Meconium staining of liquor: Meconium-stained liquor is typically associated with fetal distress, but the scenario specifically states that the liquor is clear. Therefore, meconium aspiration and its related complications are not present here, making this option incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAY-:-The sudden onset of fetal heart rate decelerations after an amniotomy, especially with a high fetal station (head 4/5th palpable), strongly suggests cord prolapse as the cause. The fetal heart rate dips, clear liquor, and the relatively unengaged fetal head make this the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A primigravida k/c/o GDM managed on oral hypogylyemic agents, presents to labour room at 38 weeks gestation. The obstetrician assesses her Bishop score prior to induction of labour. Which of the following is not a component of Modified Bishop's score?
questions.solution:
This is not a component of the Modified Bishop's score. The Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) is used to measure the amount of amniotic fluid to assess fetal well-being, but it does not relate to cervical favourability for labor induction.

Options:

a. Cervical dilatation:

  • Correct: This is an essential component of the Bishop score. Cervical dilation refers to the opening of the cervix and is measured in centimeters. The more dilated the cervix, the more favourable it is for labor induction.

b. Cervical length:

  • Correct: In the Bishop score, this is represented by cervical effacement, which refers to the thinning or shortening of the cervix. It is typically expressed as a percentage. A higher percentage of effacement indicates a more favourable cervix for labor induction.

c. Station of the presenting part:

  • Correct: The station refers to the position of the fetal head (or presenting part) in relation to the ischial spines. It is graded on a scale from -3 to +3, with higher values indicating the head is lower in the pelvis, which is favourable for labor induction.

KEY TAKEAWAY-MODIFIED BISHOP'S SCORE

SCORE:

1.<6: Unfavourable for induction.

2.>/=6: favourable for induction of labor(cervix is ripe)

Reference: FOGSI GCPR on Induction of Labor

choices.text: In more than 90% of the women, labor starts spontaneously in 3 weeks of diagnosis
Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy has been reported in 25% of women who retain a dead fetus for more than 4 weeks
If induction is delayed for more than 48 hours, woman should have testing for disseminated coagulation failure twice a week
Immediate delivery within next 6 hours has to be done

questions.text: A 32 year old G4P3L3 woman comes to ER with loss of fetal movements since last 12 hours. She is at 37 weeks' gestation, vertex presentation with adequate pelvis, not in labour. USG was done which showed intrauterine fetal death. All her previous pregnancies culminated in term normal vaginal deliveries. Which of the following statements is false regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
Immediate delivery within 6 hours is not mandatory in all cases of intrauterine fetal death unless there are other maternal risks or complications. Generally, induction of labor is planned within a reasonable time (24-48 hours), but some women may choose to wait for spontaneous labor, provided they are monitored for complications such as DIC.

Here's the option-wise explanation:

a. In more than 90% of the women, labor starts spontaneously in 3 weeks of diagnosis

  • True. Spontaneous labor generally occurs within 2 to 3 weeks after the diagnosis of intrauterine fetal death in most women.

b. Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy has been reported in 25% of women who retain a dead fetus for more than 4 weeks

  • True. Prolonged retention of a dead fetus (beyond 4 weeks) increases the risk of disseminated intravascular coagulopathy (DIC) due to the release of thromboplastin from the necrotic placenta and fetus into the maternal circulation.

c. If induction is delayed for more than 48 hours, woman should have testing for disseminated coagulation failure twice a week

  • True. Regular monitoring of coagulation parameters, including fibrinogen levels and platelet counts, is recommended to detect early signs of DIC in women who retain the fetus for an extended period.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

IOL in case of Intrauterine Fetal Demise

  • The woman and her partner should be supported and counselled to cope with the situation.
  • Woman should be offered a choice of immediate induction of labor or expectant management. However, in the presence of conditions like sepsis, preeclampsia or abruption, immediate delivery should be planned.
  • Although most patients will desire prompt delivery, immediate delivery is not critical.
  • In more than 90% of the women, labor starts spontaneously in 2-3 weeks of diagnosis.
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy has been reported in 25% of women who retain a dead fetus for more than 4 weeks.
  • If induction is delayed for more than 48 hours, woman should have testing for disseminated coagulation failure twice a week.
  • For induction of labor, PGE2 and oxytocin can be used. The use of misoprostol is off label.

Reference: FOGSI GCPR (Good Clinical Practice Recommendations) on Induction of Labor

choices.text: In women with favourable cervix , amniotomy followed by oxytocin infusion is advisable
In women with unfavourable cervix, use of mechanical methods like transcervical Foley catheter is the preferred method for induction of labor, followed by amniotomy and oxytocin
PGE1 tablets can be used for this purpose
Stringent monitoring is required as there is a risk of uterine rupture

questions.text: A 28 year old G2P1L1 with previous LSCS wants to undergo a vaginal delivery. There are no contraindications to TOLAC (Trial of Labor After Caesarean). She is assessed at 39 weeks & IOL is planned. Which of the following is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Prostaglandins, particularly PGE1 (misoprostol), are generally contraindicated or used with extreme caution in TOLAC because of the higher risk of uterine rupture. Mechanical methods and oxytocin are preferred for labor induction in such cases.

Here is the option-wise explanation:

a. In women with favourable cervix, amniotomy followed by oxytocin infusion is advisable

  • True. For women with a favourable cervix, amniotomy (artificial rupture of membranes) followed by oxytocin is an accepted and safe method for inducing labor in a TOLAC scenario. Oxytocin helps enhance contractions, and careful monitoring is required to detect early signs of uterine rupture.

b. In women with unfavourable cervix, use of mechanical methods like transcervical Foley catheter is the preferred method for induction of labor, followed by amniotomy and oxytocin

  • True. Mechanical methods such as a Foley catheter are preferred for cervical ripening in women attempting TOLAC with an unfavourable cervix. These methods have a lower risk of uterine rupture compared to pharmacological methods like prostaglandins.

d. Stringent monitoring is required as there is a risk of uterine rupture

  • True. Close monitoring of both mother and fetus is essential in TOLAC because of the increased risk of uterine rupture, particularly with the use of labor-inducing agents.

KEY TAKE AWAY:- IOL in Previous Cesarean Section

  • The essential prerequisite for induction of labor in a woman with previous caesarean is the availability of facilities for maternal-fetal monitoring and emergency caesarean section.
  • In women with favorable cervix, amniotomy followed by oxytocin infusion is advisable
  • In women with unfavorable cervix, use of mechanical methods like transcervical Foley catheter is the preferred method for induction of labor, followed by amniotomy and oxytocin.
  • The use of prostaglandins is contraindicated for use in women with a scarred uterus because of a high risk of uterine rupture.

Reference: FOGSI GCPR (Good Clinical Practice Recommendations) on Induction of Labor

questions.text: Drug of choice for uterine hyperstimulation syndrome:
questions.solution:
Terbutaline, a β2-adrenergic agonist, is the drug of choice for uterine hyperstimulation syndrome. It acts rapidly to relax the uterine muscles and stop excessive uterine contractions.

a. Glyceryl trinitrate

  • Incorrect. Although glyceryl trinitrate (GTN), a nitric oxide donor, has been used as a tocolytic in some cases, it is not the drug of choice for uterine hyperstimulation syndrome due to its systemic vasodilatory effects.

b. Atosiban

  • Incorrect. Atosiban is an oxytocin receptor antagonist used to inhibit preterm labor, but it is not the first choice for managing uterine hyperstimulation syndrome, which needs immediate tocolytic action.

d. MgSO4

  • Incorrect. Magnesium sulfate is primarily used for neuroprotection in preterm labor and for preventing seizures in preeclampsia, not for managing uterine hyperstimulation.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

questions.text: Identify this instrument used to perform amniotomy/low rupture of membranes?
questions.solution:
Steps of Low Rupture of Membranes

  • FHR status is monitored before and after the procedure.
  • The patient is in lithotomy position.
  • Full surgical asepsis is to be taken.
  • Two fingers are introduced into the vagina smeared with antiseptic ointment.
  • The index finger is passed through the cervical canal beyond the internal os.
  • The membranes are swept free from the lower segment as far as reached by the finger.
  • With one or two fingers still in the cervical canal with the palmar surface upwards, a long Kocher's forceps (as shown in the figure) OPTION C with the blades closed or an amnion hook is introduced along the palmar aspect of the fingers up to the membranes. The blades are opened to seize the membranes and are torn by twisting movements. This is followed by visible escape of amniotic fluid.

Other options:

a. Allis forceps
Allis forceps are primarily used for grasping and holding tissues during surgery. They have a toothed design, which allows them to securely hold dense tissues like fascia or skin. Allis forceps are often used in procedures requiring tissue traction.

b. Heaney forceps
Heaney forceps are used in gynecological surgeries, particularly in hysterectomies, to clamp and ligate the uterine ligaments and blood vessels. They have a curved tip and serrated jaws to provide a strong grip on tissue.

d. Mosquito forceps

  • Uses:
    Mosquito forceps are small, curved or straight hemostatic forceps used to clamp small blood vessels and control bleeding during surgery. They are commonly used in delicate procedures, particularly in vascular or pediatric surgeries.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Kocher's forceps-Amniotomy

Allis forceps- used for grasping and holding tissues during surgery

Heaney forceps - used to clamp and ligate the uterine ligaments and blood vessels.

Mosquito forceps- are small, curved or straight hemostatic forceps used to clamp small blood vessels and control bleeding during surgery

choices.text: Diabetes is an absolute contraindication to administration of Antenatal corticosteroids
Additional insulin should be given according to an agreed protocol while administering antenatal corticosteroids
Corticosteroid administration is associated with an increased risk of neonatal hypoglycemia
Maternal blood glucose levels rise shortly after corticosteroid administration & can remain elevated for up to ~5 days

questions.text: A 24 year old G2P1L1, known case of Type 1 DM controlled on insulin, presents to LR at 32 weeks of gestation with labour pains & early cervical changes. Which of the following statements regarding administration of antenatal corticosteroids to this woman does not hold true?
questions.solution:
• Diabetes is NOT an absolute contraindication to antenatal corticosteroid therapy.

Options:

b) Additional insulin should be given according to an agreed protocol while administering antenatal corticosteroids
This statement is true. It is important to adjust insulin doses and closely monitor blood glucose levels during corticosteroid therapy to manage the expected rise in maternal blood glucose.

c) Corticosteroid administration is associated with an increased risk of neonatal hypoglycemia
This statement is true. Cohort studies have shown that the administration of corticosteroids prior to caesarean section at term (after 37+0 weeks' gestation) in women with diabetes (gestational and pre-existing), is associated with increased rates of neonatal hypoglycaemia. Administration of corticosteroids can lead to an increased risk of neonatal hypoglycemia due to effects on fetal insulin production.

d) Maternal blood glucose levels rise shortly after corticosteroid administration & can remain elevated for up to ~5 days
This statement is true. Steroids, when administered, need close monitoring of serum glucose levels, which can remain elevated for ~ 5 days.

Key TAKEAWAY- Diabetes is not an absolute contraindication to the use of antenatal corticosteroids. While careful monitoring of blood glucose levels is necessary, corticosteroids can be beneficial for fetal lung maturity.

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 74, Antenatal corticosteroids to reduce neonatal morbidity & mortality
